title: 'Pitch Me One More Time: Using Virtual Reality to Overcome Stage Fright in
  Pitching'

encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>

In M. Orel, M. Cerne, &#38; S. I. Wong (Eds.), <i>Humanizing the Digital Workspace: Creativity, Innovation and Leadership in the Age of Technology</i> (pp. 493–518). Springer Nature. <a href="https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-76902-3_20">https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-76902-3_20</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-DKFCRXAF" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-DKFCRXAF" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Vibeto et al. developed a virtual reality (VR) pitch simulator at the University of Inland Norway to help students overcome stage fright and improve their presentation skills. This chapter from an anthology examines how the simulator creates a virtual environment that mimics the stress of real-life presentations, allowing users to practice in a safe and controlled setting. By using VR's immersive features, the simulator incorporates exposure therapy techniques to help manage public speaking anxiety. Through surveys and interviews, the authors found that the simulator effectively enhances pitching skills and reduces stage fright. The study highlights VR's potential in education and workplace training, emphasizing the importance of audiovisual feedback in improving the simulation experience, while noting the need for further research in this area.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-DKFCRXAF" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Virtual Reality, Pitch Simulator, Stage Fright, Public Speaking, Exposure Therapy, Higher Education
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-DKFCRXAF" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    The chapter explores the use of a virtual reality (VR) pitch simulator (PS) developed by authors of this chapter at University of Inland Norway (INN) for the purpose of training our bachelor’s degree students in game development and simulation. The simulator is designed to improve pitching skills by creating a virtual environment that mimics the stress and emotional challenges found in actual presentations. This allows users to practice and improve their skills in a controlled setting. It incorporates elements of exposure therapy, using VR’s immersive capabilities to help users manage anxiety related to public speaking. Utilizing a mixed-method approach, including surveys and interviews, the effectiveness of the simulator is assessed. Results suggest the simulator’s success in providing a safe, realistic environment for pitch practice, improving skills, and alleviating stage fright. The findings underscore VR’s potential in workplace training and higher education, emphasizing the role of audiovisual feedback in enhancing the VR simulation experience but also the need for further research on VR’s audiovisual design, particularly in exposure therapy contexts.
  </article>
